title: Erdős Problem #852: Maximal Runs of Distinct Consecutive Prime Gaps
description: Let h(x) be the maximal length of a sequence of consecutive distinct prime gaps among primes below x. Is h(x) > (log x)^c? Is h(x) = o(log x)? Brun's sieve shows h(x) → ∞.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős posed this question about the structure of consecutive prime gaps in 1985. The problem asks for the growth rate of h(x), the maximal length of a run of distinct consecutive prime gaps below x. Brun's sieve establishes that h(x) → ∞, but the precise growth rate remains unknown.
overview.problemStatement: Let dₙ = pₙ₊₁ − pₙ. Define h(x) as the maximal k such that some consecutive run dₙ, dₙ₊₁, …, dₙ₊ₖ₋₁ with pₙ < x has all distinct values. Is h(x) > (log x)^c for some c > 0? Is h(x) = o(log x)?
overview.proofStrategy: We axiomatize the prime sequence, prime gaps, and the notion of distinct-gap runs. The function h(x) is defined with witness and optimality properties. Brun's divergence result and the two open conjectures are stated.
keyInsights: Prime gaps dₙ = pₙ₊₁ − pₙ encode the local distribution of primes
Brun's sieve ensures h(x) → ∞: long runs of distinct gaps exist
The lower bound conjecture (log x)^c suggests polynomial-in-log growth
The upper bound o(log x) would place h(x) strictly below logarithmic scale

sections.title: Prime Sequence and Gaps

sections.title: Distinct Gap Runs
sections.summary: Defines runs of distinct consecutive gaps and the function h(x) with witness and optimality.

sections.title: The Erdős Conjectures
sections.summary: States the lower bound (log x)^c and upper bound o(log x) conjectures.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem 852 investigates the growth rate of maximal distinct-gap runs among consecutive primes. While Brun's sieve shows h(x) → ∞, the conjectured growth rate between (log x)^c and o(log x) remains unresolved.
conclusion.implications: Determining h(x) would reveal deep structure in how prime gaps vary locally, connecting to the Hardy–Littlewood and Maier phenomena.
openQuestions: Is h(x) > (log x)^c for some constant c > 0?
What is the exact asymptotic growth rate of h(x)?
